Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the IEEE Globecom 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will provide travel support to U.S. based graduate students to attend IEEE GLOBECOM 2015 to be held in San Diego on 6 - 10 Dec 2015. IEEE GLOBECOM is a premier international conference for the dissemination of state-of-the-art communications and networking technologies and identifying future directions in the research and development areas. It is one of two flagship conferences of the IEEE Communications Society (ComSoc), together with IEEE ICC. This grant encourages participation by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Women and minorities will be especially encouraged to apply. NSF support is used exclusively to fund a group travel grant to subsidize junior researchers. No NSF funds are used to conduct the conference.

Each year IEEE GLOBECOM attracts about 3,000 submitted scientific papers and attracts roughly 2,000 leading scientists, researchers and industry practitioners from all around the world. IEEE GLOBECOM is therefore one of the most significant scientific events of the networking and communications community, a must-attend event for scientists, researchers and networking practitioners from industry and academia. It offers not only technical paper presentations but also a wide range of other educational formats, including panels, tutorials, industry presentations, posters and keynote speeches by academic and industry leaders. This student travel support will enable sharing scientific information and stimulating research interests for U.S. based students in the field of communications and networking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is used to support U.S. based undergraduate and graduate students to attend IEEE GLOBECOM 2015, the flagship conference of the IEEE Communications Society, held in San Diego on Dec. 6-10 2015. After the open call for application, 42 applicants from U.S. based universities applied for the travel grant. A selection committee is formed and the committee selected 20 students, each of which received a travel grant of $500. The selection is based on the average score of the applicant’s accepted paper. Students who have multiple accepted papers and/or from underrepresented groups have been given higher priority. Furthermore, in case where there are multiple applications from the same research group/advisor, the selection committee only selected one most qualified student.

All the 20 selected students participated the IEEE GLOBECOM 2015. They presented their papers, and had the opportunities to interact with researchers from academia, industry, and research labs. The students not only were able to attend the technical sessions of the main conference but also were able to attend panel discussions, industrial demos, posters, and keynote speeches. The conference also provided many opportunities (e.g., reception, social events, etc) for U.S. based students to mix and mingle with other students from all the rest of the world discussing technologies related to computer & information science and engineering. Furthermore, most of IEEE Technical Committee meetings are also open to the students.
